{{Forms of government}} {{Politics}} Despite its popular usage, '''anocracy''' lacks a precise definition.<ref name="ReganBell2010"/> Anocratic regimes are loosely defined as part democracy and part [[dictatorship]],<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008"/><ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal |last1= Fearon |first1= James |last2= Laitan |first2= David |title= Ethnicity, Insurgency, and Civil War |journal= American Political Science Review |date= February 2003 |volume= 97}}</ref> or as a "regime that mixes democratic with autocratic features".<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Another definition classifies anocracy as "a regime that permits some means of participation through opposition group behavior but that has incomplete development of mechanisms to redress grievances".<ref name="ReganBell2010"/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Benson |first1=Michelle |last2=Kugler |first2=Jackek |title= Power Parity, Democracy, and Severity of Internal Violence |journal= Journal of Conflict Resolution |date= April 1998 |volume= 42 |issue= 2 |pages= 196–209 |doi= 10.1177/0022002798042002004}}</ref> Scholars have also distinguished anocracies from autocracies and democracies in their capability to maintain authority, political dynamics, and policy agendas.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Marshall |first1= Monty |last2= Gurr |first2= Ted |title= Peace and conflict 2003: A global study of armed conflicts, self-determination movements, and democracy. |journal= College Park: Center for International Development and Conflict Management, University of Maryland |date= 2003}}</ref> Similarly, these regime types have democratic institutions that allow for nominal amounts of competition.<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008"/>
These regime types are particularly susceptible to outbreaks of armed conflict and unexpected or adverse changes in leadership.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014">{{cite book |last1= Marshall |first1= Monty G. |last2= Cole |first2= Benjamin R. |title= Global Report 2014 - Conflict, Governance, and State Fragility |journal= Center for Systemic Peace |date= July 23, 2014 |url= http://www.systemicpeace.org/vlibrary/GlobalReport2014.pdf}}</ref>
The operational definition of anocracy is extensively used by scholars Monty G. Marshall and Benjamin R. Cole at the [http://www.systemicpeace.org Center for Systemic Peace] and gains most of its dissemination through the [[polity data series]]. The data set aims to measure democracy in different states, and retains anocracy as one of its classification methods for regime type.<ref>{{cite web |author= Center for Systemic Peace |title= PolityProject |url= http://www.systemicpeace.org/polityproject.html}}</ref> Consequently, anocracy frequently appears in democratization literature that utilizes the polity-data set.<ref> {{cite journal |last1= Seawright |first1= Jason |last2= Collier |first2= David |title= Rival Strategies of Validation: Tools for Evaluating Measure of Democracy |journal= Comparative Political Studies |date= 2014 |volume= 47 |issue= 1 |doi=10.1177/0010414013489098 }} </ref> In a closed anocracy, competitors are drawn from the élite. In an open anocracy, others compete too.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/>
The number of anocratic regimes has steadily increased over time, with the most notable jump occurring after the [[Post Cold War era|end of the Cold War]].<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/> During the period from 1989 to 2013, the number of anocracies increased from 30 to 53.<ref name="Polity4"/> {{TOC limit|3}} ==Traits of anocracy==
=== Human rights === Due to the instability of anocratic regimes, [[human rights]] violations are significantly higher within anocracies than democratic regimes.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Vreeland |first=James Raymond |date=2008 |title=The Effect of Political Regime on Civil War: Unpacking Anocracy. |journal=Journal of Conflict Resolution |volume=52 |issue=3 |pages=401–425 |jstor=27638616 |doi=10.1177/0022002708315594}}</ref><ref name="Davenport_Armstrong_2004"/><ref name="Landman2005">{{cite journal |last=Landman |first=Todd |date=July 2005 |title=The Political Science of Human Rights |journal=British Journal of Political Science |volume=35 |issue=3 |pages=549–572 |jstor=4092244 | doi = 10.1017/s0007123405000293 }}</ref> According to Maplecroft's 2014 Human Rights Risk Atlas, eight of the top ten worst human rights violating countries are anocracies.<ref name="Maplecroft2014">{{cite web |title=Maplecroft 2014 Global Risk Analytics |website=Maplecroft |url=http://maplecroft.com/about/news/ccvi.html |accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Gates2014">{{cite news |last=Gates |first=Sara |date=4 December 2014 |title=The 10 Worst Countries For Human Rights |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/03/human-rights-risk-atlas-2014-violations-maplecroft_n_4374133.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]]}}</ref> In addition, the report categorized every current anocracy as "at risk" or at "extreme risk" of human rights offenses.<ref name="Maplecroft2014" />
The high correlation between anocratic regimes and human rights abuses denotes the nonlinear progression in a country’s transition from an autocracy to a democracy.<ref name="Fien1995">{{cite journal |last=Fein |first=Helen |date=February 1995 |title=Life Integrity Violations and Democracy in the World, 1987 |journal=Human Rights Quarterly |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=170–191 |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/journals/human_rights_quarterly/v017/17.1fein.html |doi=10.1353/hrq.1995.0001 |subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Zanger |first=Sabine |date=March 2000 |title=A Global Analysis of the Effect of Political Regime Changes on Life Integrity Violations, 1977-93 |journal=Journal of Peace Research |volume=37 |issue=2 |pages=213–233 |jstor=424921 |doi=10.1177/0022343300037002006}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Davenport |first=Christian |date=1996 |title="Constitutional Promises" and Repressive Reality: A Cross-National Time-Series Investigation of Why Political and Civil Liberties are Suppressed |journal=Journal of Politics |volume=58 |issue=3 |pages=627–54 |url=http://www.gvpt.umd.edu/davenport/jop1996.pdf |format=pdf |doi=10.2307/2960436 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Gartner |first=S S |last2=Regan |first2=P M |date=1996 |title=Threat and repression: the non-linear relationship between government and opposition violence |journal=Journal of Peace Research |volume=33 |issue=3 |pages=273–288 |jstor=425316 |doi=10.1177/0022343396033003003}}</ref> Generally, human rights violations substantially decrease when a certain threshold of full democracy is reached.<ref name="Davenport_Armstrong_2004">{{cite journal |first=Christian |last=Davenport |first2=David A. |last2=Armstrong |date=2004 |title=Democracy and the Violation of Human Rights: A Statistical Analysis from 1976 to 1996 |journal=American Journal of Political Science |volume=48 |issue=3 |pages=538–554 |jstor=1519915 |doi=10.1111/j.0092-5853.2004.00086.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Dahl |first=Robert |date=1966 |title=Political Opposition in Western Democracies |publisher=Yale University Press |isbn=9780300094787}}</ref> However, human rights abuses tend to remain the same, or even increase, as countries move from an autocratic to an anocratic regime.<ref name="Landman2005" /><ref name="Regan_Henderson_2002">{{cite journal |first=Patrick M. |last=Regan |first2=Errol A. |last2=Henderson |date=2002 |title=Democracy, Threats and Political Repression in Developing Countries: Are Democracies Internally Less Violent? |journal=Third World Quarterly |volume=23 |issue=1 |pages=119–136 |jstor=3993579 |doi=10.1080/01436590220108207}}</ref><ref name="King_1998">{{cite journal |last=King |first=John |date=1998 |title=Repression, Domestic Threat, and Interactions in Argentina and Chile |journal=Journal of Political and Military Sociology |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=1–27 |url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/1390754/repression-domestic-threat-interactions-argentina-chile |subscription=yes}}</ref>
During the revolutions of the [[Arab Spring]], [[Libya]], [[Egypt]], and [[Yemen]] all made relative progress towards more democratic regimes.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Brown |first=Nathan J. |last2=Hamzawy |first2=Amr |date=2007 |title=Arab Spring Fever |journal=The National Interest |issue=91 |pages=33–40 |jstor=42896072}}</ref> With many of the authoritarian practices of their governments remaining, the states currently fall under the category of anocracies.<ref name="Polity4">{{cite web |last1=Marshall |first1=Monty |title=Polity IV Project: Political Regime Characteristics and Transitions, 1800-2013 |url=http://www.systemicpeace.org/polity/polity4.htm |date=6 June 2014}}</ref> They are also listed as some of the most extreme human rights violating countries in the world.<ref name="Maplecroft2014" /><ref name="Gates2014" /> These violations include, but are not limited to, torture, police brutality, slavery, discrimination, unfair trials, and restricted [[freedom of expression]].<ref name="Gates2014" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Williams |first=Paul |author2=United Nations General Assembly |date=1981 |title=The International bill of human rights |publisher=Entwhistle Books |isbn=978-0-934558-07-5}}</ref> Research has shown that political protests, such as those that occurred during the [[Arab Spring]], generally lead to an increase in human right violations as the existing government tries to retain power and influence over governmental opposition.<ref name="Landman2005" /><ref name="Fien1995" /><ref>{{cite journal |author=Manuel Antonio Garreton M. |date=1994 |title=Democratisation and Human Rights |journal=Journal of Latin American Studies |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=221–234 |doi=10.1017/s0022216x00018903}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Francisco |first=R. A. |date=1996 |title=Coercion and protest: An empirical test in two democratic states |journal=American Journal of Political Science |volume=40 |issue=4 |pages=1179–1204 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/196850306?accountid=10141 |subscription=yes |doi=10.2307/2111747}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Lichbach |first=Mark Irving |date=1987 |title=Deterrence or Escalation? The Puzzle of Aggregate Studies of Repression and Dissent |journal=Journal of Conflict Resolution |volume=31 |issue=2 |pages=266–297 |url=http://www.gvpt.umd.edu/lichbach/publications/lichbach6.87.pdf |format=pdf |doi=10.1177/0022002787031002003 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Therefore, transitioning governments tend to have high levels of human rights abuses.<ref name="PoeTateKeith1999">{{cite journal |last=Poe |first=Steven C |last2=Tate |first2=C. Neal |last3=Keith |first3=Linda Camp |date=1999 |title=Repression of the Human Right to Personal Integrity Revisited: A Global Cross-National Study Covering the Years 1976-1993 |journal=International Studies Quarterly |volume=43 |issue=2 |doi=10.1111/0020-8833.00121 |pages=291–313}}</ref><ref name="Lichbach1984">{{cite journal |last=Lichbach |first=Mark |date=1984 |title=Regime Change and the Coherence of European Governments |journal=American Political Science Review |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8975651&fileId=S0003055400184679}}</ref>
In their annual Freedom in the World report, [[Freedom House]] scored state’s violations of [[civil liberties]] on a seven-point scale, with a score of seven representing the highest percentage of violations.<ref name="FITW2014">{{cite web |title=Freedom in the World 2014: Aggregate and Subcategory Scores |website=Freedom House |url=https://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world-aggregate-and-subcategory-scores#.VHJum1fF8o}}</ref> Freedom House defined civil liberty violations as the infringement of freedom of expression, associational and organizational rights, rule of law, and individual rights.<ref>{{cite web |title=Methodology |website=Freedom House |url=https://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world-2014/methodology#.VHJvwFfF8oZ}}</ref> While most consolidated democracies received scores of one, almost all anocracies were scored between four and six, due to the high percentage of civil liberties violations within most anocratic regimes.<ref name="FITW2014" />
=== Violence === Statistics show that anocracies are ten times more likely to experience intrastate conflict than democracies, and twice as likely as autocracies.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Gehem |first=M. |last2=Marten |first2=P. |last3=Schellekens |first3=M. |date=2014 |title=Balancing on the Brink: Vulnerability of states in the Middle East and North Africa |location=Hague |publisher=The Hague Centre for Strategic Studies |volume=3 |issue=23 |url=http://www.hcss.nl/reports/download/146/2456/}}</ref> One explanation for the increase in violence and conflict within anocracies is a theory known as More Murder in the Middle (MMM).<ref name="Fien1995" /><ref>{{cite journal |last=Hendrix |first=Cullen S. |last2=Wong |first2=Wendy H. |date=July 2013 |title=When Is the Pen Truly Mighty? Regime Type and the Efficacy of Naming and Shaming in Curbing Human Rights Abuses |journal=British Journal of Political Science |volume=43 |issue=3 |pages=651–672 |jstor=23526248 |doi=10.1017/s0007123412000488}}</ref> The theory argues that the unstable characteristics of anocratic regimes, which include the presence of divided elites, inequality, and violent challengers who threaten the legitimacy of the current social order, cause governing elite to resort to [[political repression]] or [[state terror]] at a much higher rate than democratic or authoritarian regimes.<ref name="Fien1995" /><ref name="Fien1995" /><ref name="Lichbach1984" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Gates |first=Scott |last2=Havard |first2=Heger |first3=Mark P. |last3=Jones |first4=Havard |last4=Strand |date=2003 |title=Institutional Inconsistency and Political Instability: The Duration of Polities |type=Unpublished manuscript, Prio Institute}}{{unreliable source? |date=November 2014}}</ref> This leads to high levels of what are termed "life-integrity violations"<ref name="Fien1995" /><ref name="PoeTateKeith1999" /><ref name="Lichbach1984" /> which include state-sponsored genocide, extrajudicial executions, and torture.<ref name="Fien1995" /><ref name="Fien1995" /><ref name="Regan_Henderson_2002"/><ref name="King_1998"/><ref name="PoeTateKeith1999" /><ref name="Lichbach1984" /><ref>{{cite journal |last=Spirer |first=H. F. |date=1990 |title=Violations of Human Rights—How Many? |journal=American Journal of Economics and Sociology |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=199–210 |doi=10.1111/j.1536-7150.1990.tb02272.x}}</ref>
State life-integrity violations can be categorized as acts of state-terror.<ref name="PoeTateKeith1999" /><ref name="Lichbach1984" /><ref>Gibney, Mark. Wood, Reed M. (2010) The Political Terror Scale (PTS): A Re-Introduction and a Comparison to CIRI."Human Rights Quarterly, Volume 32, Issue 2, 367-400. Retrieved from {{cite web|url=http://www.politicalterrorscale.org/datafiles/hrq%20pts.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120704034450/http://www.politicalterrorscale.org/datafiles/hrq%20pts.pdf |archivedate=2012-07-04 |df= }}</ref> Acts of [[terrorism]] by both governmental and outside groups are generally higher in transitioning, anocratic, governments than in either democratic or authoritarian regimes.<ref>Frey, B. S. (2004). Dealing with terrorism: Stick or carrot? Cheltenham, UK ; Northampton, MA: Edward Elgar Pub. Retrieved from http://www.bsfrey.ch/articles/C_480_08.pdf.</ref><ref name="core.kmi.open.ac.uk">Abadie, A. (2004). Poverty, political freedom, and the roots of terrorism (No. w10859). National Bureau of Economic Research. Retrieved from http://core.kmi.open.ac.uk/download/pdf/6708194.pdf</ref>[[Harvard]] Public Policy Professor [[Alberto Abadie]] argues that the tight control of authoritarian regime is likely to discourage terrorist activities within the state. However, without the stability of a clear authoritarian rule or a [[consolidated democracy]], anocracies are more open and susceptible to terrorist attacks.<ref name="core.kmi.open.ac.uk"/><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Piazza | first1 = J. A. | year = 2008 | title = Incubators of terror: Do failed and failing states promote transnational terrorism? | url = | journal = International Studies Quarterly | volume = 52 | issue = 3| pages = 469–488 | doi=10.1111/j.1468-2478.2008.00511.x}}</ref> He notes that in [[Iraq]], and previously in [[Spain]] and [[Russia]], transitions from an authoritarian regime to a democracy were accompanied by temporary increases in terrorism.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Abadie | first1 = A. | last2 = Gardeazabal | first2 = J. | year = 2003 | title = The Economic Costs of Conflict: A Case Study of the Basque Country | url = | journal = American Economic Review | volume = 93 | issue = 1| pages = 113–131 | doi=10.1257/000282803321455188}}</ref>
According to the [[Political terror scale]] (PTS), a data set which ranks state sponsored violence on a five-point scale, almost every anocracy is ranked as having a score between three and five.<ref name="politicalterrorscale.org">Gibney, M., Cornett, L., Wood, R., & Haschke, P., (2012) Political Terror Scale 1976-2012. Retrieved from http://www.politicalterrorscale.org/</ref> On the scale, a score of three indicates a state where "there is extensive political imprisonment, or a recent history of such imprisonment. Execution or other political murders and brutality may be common. Unlimited detention, with or without a trial, for political views is accepted."<ref name="politicalterrorscale.org"/> States are ranked as a four when, "civil and political rights violations have expanded to large numbers of the population. Murders, disappearances and torture are a common part of life. In spite of its generality, on this level terror affects those who interest themselves in politics or ideas."<ref name="politicalterrorscale.org"/> Scores of five are given to states where, "terror has expanded to the whole population. The leaders of these societies place no limits on the means or thoroughness with which they pursue personal or ideological goals."<ref name="politicalterrorscale.org"/> While only eleven states were given scores of five in the 2012 Political Terror Scale report, four of those states, [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Eritrea]], [[Somalia]], and [[Sudan]], were classified by the [[Polity data series]] as anocracies.<ref name="Polity4" /><ref name="politicalterrorscale.org"/>
===Civil war=== There are differing views on whether or not anocracy leads to civil war. It is debated whether or not transitions between government regimes or political violence leads to civil war.
Civil war in unstable countries are usually the outcome of a country's inability to meet the population's demands.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/> The inability for the state to provide the needs of the population leads to factionalism within the country.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/> When the factions are not able to get what they want, then they take up arms against the state.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/>
Former democracies that transition to anocracy have a greater risk of being embroiled in civil conflict.<ref name="ReganBell2010">{{cite journal |last1=Regan |first1=Patrick |last2=Bell |first2=Sam |title=Changing Lanes or Stuck in the Middle: Why Are Anocracies More Prone to Civil Wars? |journal=Political Science Quarterly |date=December 2010 |volume=63 |issue=4 |pages=747–759 |doi=10.1177/1065912909336274}}</ref> The population's awareness of what rights they had as a democratic society may compel them to fight to regain their rights and liberties. On the other hand, autocracies that transition into anocracies are less likely to break out in civil war.<ref name="ReganBell2010" /> Not all anocracies are unstable. There are many countries that are stable but are classified as anocracies, such as Russia and Saudi Arabia.<ref name="ReganBell2010" /><ref name="Polity4" /> It is the transitional qualities associated with some anocracies that are predicative of civil conflict.<ref name="ReganBell2010" /> The magnitude of the transition also affects the probability of a civil conflict. The higher magnitude of the transition, the higher likelihood of civil war.<ref name="ReganBell2010" />
However, some international relations experts use the polity data series in the formulation of their hypothesis and study and this presents a problem because the Polity IV system uses violence and civil war as a factor in their computation of a country's polity score.<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008">{{cite journal |last1=Gandhi |first1=Jennifer |last2=Vreeland |first2=James |title=Political Institutions and Civil War: Unpacking Anocracy |journal=Journal of Conflict Solutions |date=June 2008 |volume=52 |issue=3 |pages=401–425 |doi=10.1177/0022002708315594}}</ref> Two components, "the degree of institutionalization, or regulation, of political competition",<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" /> and "the extent of government restriction on political competition",<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" /> are problematic to use in any study involving Polity IV and civil war in anocratic governments. In the numeric rating system of one of these parts of Polity IV, unregulated, "may or may be characterized by violent conflict among partisan groups."<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" /> The other component says "there are relatively stable and enduring political groups - but competition among them is intense, hostile, and frequently violent."<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" /> The only thing that can be deduced concretely, is that political violence tends to lead to civil war.<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" /> There is no solid evidence to support that political institutions in an anocracy leads to civil war.<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" />
=== Broadness and complexity=== While the first three characteristics capture the instability of anocracies, another feature of anocratic regimes is its broad descriptiveness. Anocracy describes a regime type with a mix of institutional characteristics that either constrains or promotes the democratic process, "encapsulating a complex category encompassing many institutional arrangements".<ref name="ReganBell2010"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/> While anocracies demonstrate some capacity for civil society and political participation, their autocratic and democratic counterparts show considerably more or less capabilities.<ref name="ReganBell2010"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/> Thus, while scholars are easily able to identify democratic and autocratic regimes based on their respective characteristics, anocracies become a wider, "catchall" category for all other regimes.<ref name="ReganBell2010"/> Yet, despite its broadness and complexity, the convention is still used because of its relevance to civil instability as well as its usage in the Polity data series.<ref name="ReganBell2010"/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gates |first1=Scott |last2=Hegre |first2=Havard |last3=Jones |first3=Mark P. |title=Institutional inconsistency and political instability: Polity duration 1800-2000 |journal=American Journal of Political Science |date=2006 |volume=50 |pages=893–908 |doi=10.1111/j.1540-5907.2006.00222.x}}</ref>
==Examples of anocracy==
===Anocracy in Asia===
====Cambodia==== [[Cambodia]] is an example of anocracy because its government displays democratic and authoritarian aspects. Under the [[United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia]], Cambodia implemented an electoral system based on proportional representation, held legitimate elections, and instituted a parliamentary system of government.<ref name="LIT Verlag Munster">{{cite book |last1=Croissant |first1=Aurel |last2=Martin |first2=Beate |title=Between Consolidation and Crisis: Elections and Democracy in Five Nations in Southeast Asia |date=2006 |publisher=LIT Verlag Munster}}</ref> The constitution, created on 21 September 1993 indicated that Cambodia was a parliamentary government with a constitutional monarchy.<ref name="LIT Verlag Munster"/> Cambodia exhibited signs of a democratic state, especially with the presence of elections and a proportionally representative government. Following the [[1997 clashes in Cambodia|coup]] in 1997, the Cambodian government has taken more authoritarian measures to keep peace in the country.<ref name="Is Cambodia at a tipping point">{{cite news |last1=Freeman |first1=Joe |title=Is Cambodia at a tipping point? |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/10/world/asia/cambodia-protests-analysis/ |website=CNN.com |date=10 January 2014}}</ref> Protests have been suppressed violently by pro-government forces and many human rights activists and protester have been arrested by the Cambodian government.<ref name="Is Cambodia at a tipping point"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Cambodia: New Crackdown on Protesters |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/11/13/cambodia-new-crackdown-protesters |agency=Human Rights Watch |date=13 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Sovuthy |first1=Khy |title=Protesters Call for Release of Detained Activists |url=http://www.cambodiadaily.com/news/protesters-call-for-release-of-detained-activists-72391/ |website=cambodiadaily.com |date=15 November 2014}}</ref>
Cambodia shows signs of being an unstable government with abrupt changes in leadership, making it an anocratic. The initial elections led to [[FUNCINPEC]]'s victory under the leadership of [[Norodom Ranariddh|Prince Ranariddh]]. FUNCINPEC and the [[Buddhist Liberal Democratic Party]] won 68 out of 120 seats in the National Assembly.<ref name="LIT Verlag Munster"/> The [[Cambodian People's Party]], led by [[Hun Sen]], refused to accept the outcome. Although a coalitional government was created with Prince Ranariddh as the First Prime Minister and Sen as the Second Prime Minister, the deal failed as Sen led a coup d'état on July 5, 1997.<ref>{{cite news |title=A coup in Cambodia |url=http://www.economist.com/node/370230 |agency=The Economist |date=10 July 1997}}</ref> Sen and the CPP have been in power ever since and the CPP recently won a general election against the [[Cambodia National Rescue Party]] led by [[Sam Rainsy]].<ref>{{cite news |title=After Cambodia's election |url=https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21583694-opposition-leader-vanishes-when-colleagues-need-him-most-stand?zid=309&ah=80dcf288b8561b012f603b9fd9577f0e |agency=The Economist |date=17 August 2013}}</ref>
====Thailand==== [[Thailand]]'s history of leadership changes make it an anocratic state. Thailand has been undergoing constant political upheaval since 1993.<ref name="LIT Verlag Munster"/> Coups d'état and the purchase of political votes are the main causes for Thai political instability. Thailand experienced a period of political liberalization under [[Prem Tinsulanonda|General Prem Tinsulanonda]] who was an unelected Prime Minister during the 1980-1988 period.<ref name="LIT Verlag Munster"/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Leifer |first1=Michael |title=Dictionary of the Modern Politics of Southeast Asia |date=13 May 2013 |publisher=Routledge}}</ref> A series of coups ensued soon after. [[Suchinda Kraprayoon|General Suchinda Kraprayoon]] led a coup against [[Chatichai Choonhavan|Prime Minister Choonhavan]] on February 23, 1991.<ref name="February 1991 Coup">{{cite web |title=February 1991 Coup |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/thailand/coup-1991.htm |website=Globalsecurity.org}}</ref> After the [[Black May (1992)|Black May]] incident Suchinda was forced to resign and [[Anand Panyarachun]] was assigned the position of temporary prime minister.<ref name="February 1991 Coup"/> [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] won the 2001 elections and became Prime Minister of Thailand; he won again in 2005 but a [[2006 Thai coup d'état|coup]] led by the Thai military deposed Prime Minister Shinawatra in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Walker |first1=Peter |title=Thai military claims control after coup |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/sep/19/thailand |website=Theguardian.com |date=19 September 2006}}</ref> After a new [[2007 constitution of Thailand|constitution]] was adopted, [[Samak Sundaravej]] and his [[People's Power Party (Thailand)]] won the election on December 23, 2007 and Sundaravej became prime minister.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thaksin ally wins Thai election |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7158354.stm |website=news.bbc.co.uk |date=23 December 2007}}</ref> However, due to a conflict of interest, Sundaravej was ousted and [[Somchai Wongsawat]] was elected as the new prime minister.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Beech |first1=Hannah |title=Thai PM Ousted over Cookery Shows |url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1839758,00.html |website=Time.com |date=9 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Thai MPs elect new prime minister |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7620257.stm |website=news.bbc.co.uk |date=17 September 2008}}</ref> Shortly after his election, Prime Minister Wongsawat and the PPP was found to be guilty of electoral fraud and Wongsawat lost his position.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Weaver |first1=Matthew |title=Thailand prime minister to step down after court strips him of office |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/dec/02/thailand-protests-somchai-wongsawat |website=theguardian.com |date=2 December 2008}}</ref> [[Abhisit Vejjajiva]]'s election as the next prime minister was met with [[2010 Thai political protests|opposition]] by "Red Shirts."<ref>{{cite web |last1=MacKinnon |first1=Ian |title=Thai opposition leader elected PM |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/dec/15/thailand-pm-abhisit-vejjajiva |website=Theguardian.com |date=15 December 2008}}</ref> On July 3, 2011, [[Yingluck Shinawatra]], belonging to the [[Pheu Thai Party]], was elected as prime minister.<ref>{{cite news |title=A surprising new face |url=http://www.economist.com/node/18925843 |agency=The Economist |date=7 July 2011}}</ref> Following mass protests in 2013, Shinawatra was deposed by a military coup led by [[Prayut Chan-o-cha|General Chan-o-cha]], who is currently the prime minister.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hodal |first1=Kate |title=Former Thai prime minister Yingluck Shinawatra detained after coup |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/23/yingluck-shinawatra-detained-thailand-coup-military |website=Theguardian.com |date=24 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Lefevre |first1=Amy Sawitta |title=Thai capital hit by biggest protests since deadly 2010 unrest |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/24/us-thailand-protest-idUSBRE9AN09Q20131124 |website=Reuters.com |date=24 November 2013}}</ref>
====Burma==== [[Burma]], or the Republic of the Union of Myanmar, is classified as an anocracy because of adverse armed conflict, changes in leadership, and the part-democratic, part-authoritarian nature of its government. Burma had a representative democracy after it gained [[Independence Day (Burma)|independence]] from Britain. Soon after independence was achieved, there was an outbreak of various insurgencies and rebellions.<ref name="FearonLaitan">{{cite web |last1=Fearon |first1=James D. |last2=Laitin |first2=David D. |title=Burma |url=http://web.stanford.edu/group/ethnic/Random%20Narratives/BurmaRN1.2.pdf |format=pdf |website=Stanford |date=n.d.}}</ref> Many of these insurgencies were caused by divides along ethnic lines.<ref name="FearonLaitan" /> One of the most prominent civil wars in Burma, the [[Kachin conflict]], restarted in 2011 and Burma is still embroiled in a civil war.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Beech |first1=Hannah |title=Inside the Kachin War Against Burma |url=http://time.com/3598969/kachin-independence-army-kia-burma-myanmar-laiza/ |website=Time.com |date=21 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Whiteman |first1=Hilary |title=Why Kachin conflict threatens Myanmar peace |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/23/world/asia/myanmar-burma-kachin-conflict/ |website=CNN.com |date=24 January 2013}}</ref>
Burma has had a history of changes in government, usually through military coups. In 1962, General [[Ne Win]] enacted a military coup and created the [[Burma Socialist Programme Party]] which held power for 26 years.<ref name="Understanding Myanmar">{{cite web |last1=Bajoria |first1=Jayshree |title=Understanding Myanmar |url=http://www.cfr.org/human-rights/understanding-myanmar/p14385 |website=Cfr.org |date=21 June 2013}}</ref> On September 18, 1988, General [[Saw Maung]] led another military coup to return the government to the people and created the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC), renamed [[State Peace and Development Council]].<ref name="1988 Uprising and 1990 Election">{{cite web |title=1988 Uprising and 1990 Election |url=http://www.oxfordburmaalliance.org/1988-uprising--1990-elections.html |website=oxfordburmaalliance.org}}</ref> After holding free and legitimate elections in May 1990, the [[National League for Democracy]] (NLD) won with [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] at its head.<ref name="1988 Uprising and 1990 Election"/> However, the military junta refused to give up power to the NLD.<ref name="1988 Uprising and 1990 Election"/> The [[Union Solidarity and Development Party]] (USDP), backed by the military, won the 2010 elections and the military government was dissolved soon after.<ref name="Understanding Myanmar"/><ref name="bbc.com">{{cite web |title=Western states dismiss Burma's election |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-pacific-11707294 |website=bbc.com |date=8 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Burma junta disbanded as 'civilian' government sworn in |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/30/burma-civilian-governmnet-junta-disbanded |website=Theguardian.com |date=30 March 2011}}</ref>
The Burmese government shows signs of having democratic as well as authoritarian features. Burma is a pseudo-democratic state because of the elections that have been held in 1990 and 2010.<ref name="1988 Uprising and 1990 Election"/><ref name="bbc.com"/> However, both these elections were problematic because the military did not transfer power to the winning party in 1990 and the 2010 elections were seen as illegitimate.<ref name="1988 Uprising and 1990 Election"/><ref name="bbc.com"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=MacFarquhar |first1=Neil |title=U.N. Doubts Fairness of Election in Myanmar |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/22/world/asia/22nations.html?_r=0 |website=nytimes.com |date=21 October 2010}}</ref> Violent repression is the biggest signifier of the authoritarian nature of the Burmese government. The Win regime was marked by extreme oppression and human rights abuses and as a result, Burmese civilians and students [[8888 Uprising|protested]] against the government.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burma's 1988 protests |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7012158.stm |website=news.bbc.co.uk |date=25 September 2007}}</ref><ref name="The Ne Win Years: 1962-1988">{{cite web |title=The Ne Win Years: 1962-1988 |url=http://www.oxfordburmaalliance.org/1962-coup--ne-win-regime.html |website=oxfordburmaalliance.org}}</ref> The Burmese government responded violently to the protests and the [[Tatmadaw]], or Myanmar Armed Forces, killed many of the protestors.<ref name="The Ne Win Years: 1962-1988"/> After the coup in 1988 by General Maung, the protests were violently suppressed again as Maung's government proceeded to implement martial law to bring peace and order.<ref name="1988 Uprising and 1990 Election"/>
=== Anocracy in Africa=== At the end of [[World War II]], European control over its colonial territories in [[Africa]] diminished.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/> During this period of [[decolonization]] in the 1950s and 1960s, many African states gained independence.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/> Although these newly independent African states could become either democratic or autocratic regimes, manageability issues made way for autocratic regimes to come into power.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/> Most underdeveloped African states that did become democracies in this time period failed within 10 years and transitioned to autocracies.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/> For about 30 years after 1960, the number of autocratic regimes in Africa rose from 17 to 41 as the number of democratic regimes stayed around five.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/><ref name="Democracy in Africa">{{cite web |last1=Gylfason |first1=Thorvaldur |title=Democracy in Africa |url=http://www.voxeu.org/article/democracy-africa |website=www.voxeu.org}}</ref> After the collapse of [[communism]] in Europe and the rise of [[democratization]] at the end of the [[Cold War]], Africa experienced a major political transformation.<ref name="Democracy in Africa"/> In the 1990s, the number of autocracies decreased to nine and the number of democracies increased to nine as many African countries remained stuck in an anocratic state.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/><ref name="Democracy in Africa"/> By 2012, Africa had three autocracies, 17 democracies, and 30 anocracies.<ref name="Democracy in Africa"/> By 2013, the majority of African countries remained either open or closed anocracies.<ref name="Marshall_Cole_2014"/> As African states transition from autocracy to anocracy and anocracy to democracy, electoral conflicts and violence remains prevalent.<ref name="Lexington Books">{{cite book |last1=Adebayo |first1=Akanmu G. |title=Managing Conflicts in Africa's Democratic Transitions |date=2012 |publisher=Lexington Books |pages=233–252 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0XCM1QgmVnMC&pg=PA239&lpg=PA239&dq=africa+and+anocracy&source=bl&ots=JGTtw0s_T6&sig=yqkp9FSbJwH-yFxx7CBDybqXo3g&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Aw9XVMztCNC0oQSQp4CoBg&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=africa%20and%20anocracy&f=false}}</ref>
====Nigeria==== With a polity score of four in 2014, [[Nigeria]] is categorized as an open anocracy, transitioning closer to democracy than autocracy.<ref name="Polity4" /> In recent years, Nigeria has displayed characteristics of anocratic regimes including political corruption and electoral riggings.<ref name="Nigeria's Rigged Democracy">{{cite journal |last1=Herskovits |first1=Jean |title=Nigeria's Rigged Democracy |journal=Foreign Affairs |date=Jul–Aug 2007 |volume=86 |issue=4 |pages=115–130 |jstor=20032419}}</ref> Following years of military rule after gaining independence in 1960 to 1999 with excluding 1979-83, the 2007 general elections marked the first time in Nigerian history that political leadership could be passed from one civilian to another through the process of election.<ref name="Nigeria's Rigged Democracy"/> However, in late 2006, just months before the April 2007 general election, former president [[Olusegun Obasanjo]] used state institutions to try to defeat political opponents as he attempted to win his third straight presidential term.<ref name="Nigeria's Rigged Democracy"/><ref name="Maduekwe">{{cite news|last=Maduekwe |first=Ojo M. |title=Nigeria: Between Anocracy and Authoritarianism |url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/nigeria-between-anocracy-and-authoritarianism/186082/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20141108051237/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/nigeria-between-anocracy-and-authoritarianism/186082/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=8 November 2014 |agency=This Day |date=12 August 2014 }}</ref> Using the [https://efccnigeria.org/efcc/ Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC)], an institution created by Obasanjo's administration, the former president had some of his political enemies and their family members either arrested or detained.<ref name="Maduekwe"/> Despite the electoral conflicts, some Nigerians view their country as running on democratic principles because military power has been controlled by political elites for 15 years.<ref name="Maduekwe"/> However, the aforementioned electoral conflicts combined with state governors using legislative and judiciary power to repeatedly win elections suggests that Nigeria remains an anocracy.<ref name="Maduekwe"/> Former president [[Goodluck Jonathan]] was accused of abusing his power in an attempt to remain in office past 2015, despite claiming his presidency advocated democratic principles.<ref name="Maduekwe"/>
====Zimbabwe==== When [[Robert Mugabe]] gained presidency in 1980, [[Zimbabwe]] was listed as an open anocracy with a polity score of four.<ref name="Polity4" /><ref name="Autocracy and Anocracy">{{cite web |last1=Schofield |first1=Norman |last2=Gallego |first2=Maria |title=Autocracy and Anocracy |url=https://polisci.wustl.edu/files/polisci/imce/17.xxxanocracies-sept7-final-2011.pdf}}</ref> By 1987, the country had almost fully transitioned to an authoritarian regime with a polity score of negative six, which made it a closed anocracy.<ref name="Polity4" /> After remaining on the border between an authoritarian regime and closed anocracy for over a decade, Zimbabwe's polity score increased in the early 2000s. Currently, Zimbabwe has a polity score of 4, making it an open anocracy.<ref name="Polity4" /> In recent years, Zimbabwe has moved toward becoming a more democratic regime, but electoral conflicts and human rights violations still exist leaving Zimbabwe as an anocratic regime.<ref name="Autocracy and Anocracy"/><ref name="jstor.org">{{cite journal |last1=Sibanda |first1=Nomore |title=Zimbabwe - careless of human rights |journal=International Union Rights |date=1997 |volume=4 |issue=4 |page=23 |jstor=41937098}}</ref>
When Zimbabwe was a closed anocracy in the late 1990s, the country experienced major human rights violations.<ref name="jstor.org"/> Labor strikes were common as employers did not listen to the demands of their employers and real wages fell by 60 percent from 1992 to 1997.<ref name="jstor.org"/> The labor strikes that occurred in the late 1990s were declared illegal by the government of Zimbabwe and blame was put on poor, working class citizens.<ref name="jstor.org"/> As labor laws continued hurting workers, health services declined and housing projects stagnated.<ref name="jstor.org"/>
Since becoming president in 1980, Mugabe has used a variety of tactics to remain in power that have led to major electoral conflicts over the years.<ref name="Autocracy and Anocracy"/> In the March 2008 presidential election, the electoral body reported that [[Morgan Tsvangirai]], the presidential candidate of the opposing party, received more votes than Mugabe.<ref name="Autocracy and Anocracy"/> However, because Tsvangirai received 48 percent of the vote and not full majority, it was announced that a runoff would take place. Using intimidation tactics, including murder threats, Mugabe and his party forced Tsvangirai to withdraw from the runoff and Mugabe remained in power.<ref name="Autocracy and Anocracy"/> A U.S. led [https://www.un.org/en/sc/ United Nations security council] to impose sanctions on Mugabe failed and talks about power-sharing between Mugabe and Tsvangirai ended soon after the runoff.<ref name="Autocracy and Anocracy"/> After opposing party candidate [[Lovemore Moyo]] won [[List of Speakers of the House of Assembly of Zimbabwe|Speaker of the Legislature]], a power-sharing coalition was finally set up in September 2008 in which Tsvangirai was named [[Prime Minister]].<ref name="Autocracy and Anocracy"/> Following this, the polity score of Zimbabwe increased from one to four by 2010.<ref name="Polity4" /> Yet, in 2013, Mugabe won his seventh straight presidential term and the election was criticized for being rigged to allow Mugabe to win.<ref name="Autocracy and Anocracy"/>
====Uganda==== In the 1990s, [[Uganda]] transitioned from an autocracy to a closed anocracy.<ref name="Polity4" /> Although Uganda saw a jump in its polity score in the mid-2000s, it has retained a polity score of negative two for the last decade.<ref name="Polity4" /> Uganda is populated by many ethnic groups with the [[Buganda]] group, the largest of these groups, making up 17 percent of the population.<ref name="Uganda Country Profile">{{cite web|title=Uganda Country Profile |url=http://www.tulane.edu/~internut/Countries/Uganda/ugandaxx.html |website=www.tulane.edu |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405031435/http://www.tulane.edu/~internut/Countries/Uganda/ugandaxx.html |archivedate=2015-04-05 }}</ref> Since Uganda gained independence in 1962, incessant conflict has ensued between the approximately 17 ethnic groups, which has led to political instability.<ref name="Uganda Country Profile"/> Dictator [[Idi Amin]] was responsible for around 300,000 deaths under his rule from 1971-1979 and guerrilla warfare from 1980-1985 under [[Milton Obote]] killed 100,000 people.<ref name="Uganda Country Profile"/> Human rights abuses under both of these rulers led to even more deaths from 1971 to 1985.<ref name="Uganda Country Profile"/>
In the early 1990s, Uganda experienced large-scale violent dissent as the country experienced more rebellions and guerrilla warfare.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Carey |first1=Sabine C. |title=Rebellion in Africa: Disaggregating the Effect of Political Regimes |journal=Journal of Peace Research |date=January 2007 |volume=44 |issue=1 |pages=47–64 |jstor=27640452|doi=10.1177/0022343307072176}}</ref> As a result of the warring, the government called for non-party presidential and legislative elections in the mid-1990s.<ref name="Uganda Country Profile"/> A period of relative peace followed as a [[common law]] legal system was instituted in 1995. During this period, Uganda transitioned from an authoritarian regime to a closed anocracy.<ref name="Polity4" /><ref name="Uganda Country Profile"/> The political situation of Uganda has seen little improvement under the rule of [[Yoweri Museveni]] who has maintained power since 1986.<ref name="Uganda Country Profile"/> Museveni has retained power due to the fact that other political organizations in Uganda cannot sponsor candidates.<ref name="Uganda Country Profile"/> Only Museveni and his [[National Resistance Movement]] (NRM) can operate without any limitations leading to electoral conflicts and violence.<ref name="Uganda Country Profile"/>
====Somalia==== [[Somalia]] was labeled as an autocracy from 1969 to 2012 with a polity score of negative seven throughout the entire period.<ref name="Polity4" /> From 1969 to 1991 [[Siad Barre]] was the military dictator of the [[Somali Democratic Republic]].<ref name="Somalia Profile">{{cite news |title=Somalia Profile |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-14094503 |agency=BBC |publisher=BBC News |date=21 October 2014}}</ref> After Barre was overthrown in 1991, two decades of chaos ensued as civil war broke out and rival warlords fought to gain power. The consistent fighting of tribal leaders and warlords made the country unable to deal with natural disasters, droughts, and famines causing a combined 500,000 deaths in the famines of 1992 and 2010-2012.<ref name="Somalia Profile"/>
After years of being split into fiefdoms, the main Somali warlords established an agreement to appoint a new president in 2004. However, this plan failed when Islamist insurgents, including the radical youth militia [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|al-Shabaab]] who had links to [[Al-Qaeda]], gained control over much of southern Somalia from 2006 to 2008.<ref name="Somalia Profile"/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bruton |first1=Bronwyn |title=In the Quicksands of Somalia: Where Doing Less Helps More |journal=Foreign Affairs |date=Nov–Dec 2009 |volume=88 |issue=6 |pages=79–94 |jstor=20699717}}</ref> With the assistance of international peace keeping offensives and the Kenyan army, the Islamist insurgents were forced to withdraw in 2012.<ref name="Somalia Profile"/> In the same year, the first formal parliament in over 20 years was appointed in Somalia.<ref name="Somalia Profile"/> The newly formed parliament chose [[Hassan Sheikh Mohamud]] as the new president in September 2012. With international assistance, the Somali government has been able to rebuild itself and the country has been relatively more stable recently.<ref name="Somalia Profile"/> Since 2013, Somalia has retained a polity score of five and is listed as an open anocracy.<ref name="Polity4" />
===Anocracy in Europe===
====Russia==== [[Russia]], as of 2016, is classified as an open anocracy on the [[Polity data series|Polity IV scale]], which means that it is between one and five in its score.<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" /> Open anocracies hold democratic elections, but ones that are not very free, and the country does not grant some rights of{{clarify|date=July 2017}} the population.<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" />{{qn|date=July 2017}} The press is strictly monitored, as is incoming news from the outside world.<ref name="GandhiVreeland2008" /> Russia allegedly has all of these characteristics.<ref>Compare: {{cite news |last1= Lally |first1= Kathy |last2= Englund |first2= Will |title= In Russia, politics and nationalist pride are basis of Putin's anti-American turn |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/in-russia-politics-and-nationalist-pride-are-basis-of-putins-anti-american-turn/2013/09/14/2f43c392-1c86-11e3-80ac-96205cacb45a_story.html |website= Washingtonpost.com |date= 14 September 2013 | quote= After demonstrators protesting rigged elections took to the streets against him in December 2011, Putin began conjuring up ways to isolate these liberal, Western-leaning, middle-class Russians from the rest of the country, the theory goes.}}</ref>
====Ukraine==== Late in 2013 the then president of [[Ukraine]], [[Viktor Yanukovych]], conducted talks with the [[European Union]] about establishing closer ties. Instead, Yanukovych backed out of the prospective agreement and turned to Russia for some multibillion-dollar loans.<ref name="cnn.com">{{cite news |last1= Smith-Spark |first1= Laura |last2= Magnay |first2= Diana |title= Ukraine's President Viktor Yanukovych defends handling of political crisis |url= http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/30/world/europe/ukraine-protests/index.html |website= CNN.com |date= 30 January 2014 | quote = After Yanukovych's U-turn in November on the planned EU trade deal, he and Putin agreed to a $15 billion deal for Russia to buy Ukrainian debt.}}</ref> Civil unrest broke out in the streets of Kiev, with the citizens showing their anger over the president spurning the EU. Yanukovych fled to Russia (February 2014) as the protests got out of hand. An interim government took office in early 2014, with new elections scheduled for later in 2014. A referendum held to determine if Crimea was to become part of Russia came under criticism.<ref>{{cite news |last1= Vasilyeva |first1= Nataliya |title= Ukraine Breakaway Regions Hold Criticized Elections |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/11/02/ukraine-elections_n_6090456.html |website= Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2 November 2014}} {{dead link|date=July 2017}}</ref> Questionable plebiscites are a characteristic of anocracy{{Citation needed|date= August 2016}}. In February 2014 the death toll in [[Kiev]] rose to almost 100 due to escalating clashes between demonstrators and security forces.<ref>{{cite news |last1= Kramer |first1= Andrew E. |last2= Higgins |first2= Andrew |title= Ukraine's Forces Escalate Attacks Against Protesters |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/21/world/europe/ukraine.html?_r=0 |website= nytimes.com |date= 20 February 2014}}</ref> This, in combination with the government's loose hold on its subjects, and foreign interference makes Ukraine an example of a [[transitional state]], one that is in an anocratic stage.<ref name="ReganBell2010" />
However, the duration of the period where the term (i.e. 'Anocracy') might be considered relevant to Ukraine did not last long, but, rather, there was a number of outbreaks and they fitted mostly into the Maidan period (i.e. from 30 November 2013 till 20 February 2014): notably, they concentrated around certain events that earmarked the intensification of the hostilities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Drotenko|first=Valerii|title=Euro-Maidan: Chronicles and context (up to 27.01.2014)|url=https://www.academia.edu/9632173/Euro-Maidan_Chronicles_and_context_up_to_27.01.2014_|language=en}}</ref>
Otherwise, the Ukrainians as a nation have demonstrated sound ability to self-organization, self-discipline and absence of temptations to indulge in mass criminality, which normally accompanies such events. In contrary - the acting authorities of that period (Viktor [[Viktor Yanukovych|Yanukovych]] and his apparatus) were the ones to instigate and provoke criminality: from using notorious thugs (widely referred there to as [[Titushky|'titushki']]) to outright releasing criminals from the prisons in the neighbourhood of capital city Kyiv<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/ukraine-protesters-take-control-of-kiev-seize-presidents-office/|title=Protesters seize Ukraine president's office, take control of Kiev|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en}}</ref> - with the aim to distabilize the overall situation and compromise the post-Maidan authorities.
Theoretically, the secession of territories ([[Crimea]] on the [[Donbass separatism|South and Donbass]] on the [[Eastern Ukraine|East]]) might be other tokens to justify the classification of Ukraine as anocracy. However, it has been proved that in both cases Russia stood behind the local separatists: vote on [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|Crimean referendum]] led to international condemnation and the public opinion might have been skewed [[Propaganda in post-Soviet Russia|by massive propaganda in Russian mass media]] (which dominated the peninsula's media landscape) as well as temporary vacuum of central power after [[Viktor Yanukovych|Yanukovych]] has fled the country; whereas the same has been attempted in the rest of South-East (e.g. [[Kharkiv]], [[Odessa|Odesa]], [[Kherson]], [[Dnipro]], etc.), but succeeded only in extreme South-Eastern part of [[Donetsk Oblast|Donetsk]] and [[Luhansk Oblast|Luhansk]] [[Oblasts of Ukraine|oblasts]] - and would have been inevitably ended without both open and implicit [[Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)|Russian intervention and military aid]].
====Yugoslavia==== [[Yugoslavia]] was a large country in Europe until the 1990s. It was mostly held together in the latter half of the 20th century by [[Josip Broz Tito]],<ref name="The Former Yugoslavia">{{cite web |last1= Rosenberg |first1= Matt |title= The Former Yugoslavia |url= http://geography.about.com/od/politicalgeography/a/fmryugoslavia.htm |website= geography.about.com | quote = Marshal Tito was able to keep Yugoslavia unified from the formation of the country from 1945 until his death in 1980.}}</ref> a president strongman who ruled by force of personality.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Tensions rose between the different ethnic groups in Yugoslavia<ref>{{cite web |last1= Rosenberg |first1= Matt |title= The Former Yugoslavia |url= http://geography.about.com/od/politicalgeography/a/fmryugoslavia.htm |website= geography.about.com | quote = Following Tito's death in 1980, factions in Yugoslavia became agitated and demanded more autonomy. It was the fall of the USSR in 1991 that finally broke up the jigsaw puzzle of a state. About 250,000 were killed by wars and 'ethnic cleansing' in the new countries of the former Yugoslavia.}}</ref> - including the Croats, Serbs, Albanians, Bosnians, Montenegrins, Macedonians, Slovenians, and Kosovars. New separate states formed: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, and Slovenia.<ref> {{cite web |last1= Rosenberg |first1= Matt |title= The Former Yugoslavia |url= http://geography.about.com/od/politicalgeography/a/fmryugoslavia.htm |website= geography.about.com | quote = This overview should help clear up some confusion about what's in place of the former Yugoslavia now.}} </ref> The destructive [[Yugoslav Wars]] in the 1990s cost many lives. The fragmentation of power in Yugoslavia, disputed elections, and the discontent of the differentiated ethnic political groups are the main factors resulting in Yugoslavia and its successor states{{which|date=July 2017}} being{{when|date=July 2017}} considered{{by whom|date=July 2017}} anocracies.<ref name="What is Democratic Consolidation">{{cite journal |last1= Schedler |first1= Andreas |title= What is Democratic Consolidation? |journal= Journal of Democracy |date= 1998 |volume= 9 |issue= 2 |pages= 91–107 |doi= 10.1353/jod.1998.0030}}</ref> The political stagnation, and the non-civilian control of the military during the civil wars play a large part as well.<ref> {{cite web |title=Serbo-Croatian War / Homeland War |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/croatia.htm |website=globalsecurity.org }} </ref>
==Successful transitions== Anocratic regimes are often implicitly mentioned in democratic transition literature.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Huntington |first1=Samuel |title=The Third Wave: Democratization in the Late Twentieth Century |date=1991 |publisher=University of Oklahoma Press |location=Norman, OK}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Diamond |first1=Larry |title=Developing Democracy: Toward Consolidation |date=1999 |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Linz |first1=Juan |title=Transition to Democracy |journal=Washington Quarterly |date=Summer 1990 |volume=143 |issue=64}}</ref> There are numerous examples of regimes that have successfully transitioned to democracy from anocracy.
===Mexico=== [[Mexico]]'s transition from an anocratic to democratic regime occurred during the 1980s and 1990s on the electoral stage. This period was characterized by the rise of multiple parties, decline of power from the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party]], and decentralization of power from the national level into municipalities.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lawson |first1=Chappell |title=Mexico's Unfinished Transition: Democratization and Authoritarian Enclaves in Mexico |journal=Mexican Studies |date=Summer 2000 |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=267–287 |doi=10.1525/msem.2000.16.2.03a00040}}</ref> The democratization process produced competitive elections with less voting fraud, culminating with the [[Mexican general election, 1994|1994 presidential election]].<ref name="Oxford University Press">{{cite book |last1=Camp |first1=Roderic |title=The Oxford Handbook of Mexican Politics |date=2012 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=198 Madison Avenue, New York, NY |isbn=978-0-19-537738-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cornelius |first1=Wayne |title=Mexico's Delayed Democratization |journal=Foreign Policy |date=Summer 1994 |volume=95 |pages=53–71 |doi=10.2307/1149423}}</ref> There was also a documented increase in the role of media and journalism during this period, which led to the creation of various special interest groups, such as those representing the environment, indigenous rights, and women's rights.<ref name="Oxford University Press"/> However, violence continues to remain a characteristic of Mexico's local elections.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Negroponte |first1=Dianna Villiers |title=Political Violence Surrounding Mexico's Local Elections |url=http://www.brookings.edu/blogs/up-front/posts/2013/07/17-political-violence-mexico-local-elections-negroponte |website=Brookings Institution}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Zabluovsky |first1=Karla |title=Mexico's Election Violence Said to Be the Worst in Years |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/07/world/americas/mexicos-election-violence-is-said-to-be-worst-in-years.html |agency=New York Times |date=July 6, 2013 |work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Wilkinson |first1=Tracy |title=Political violence casts shadow over upcoming Mexico Election |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jul/03/world/la-fg-mexico-election-violence-20130704 |agency=Los Angeles Times |date=July 3, 2013}}</ref>
===Taiwan=== In the aftermath of World War II, Japan surrendered [[Taiwan]] to the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]]. The constitution that the Republic of China used to govern Taiwan guaranteed civil rights and elections, but was ignored in favor of rule under martial law.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Tien |first1=Hung-Mao |last2=Shiau |first2=Chyuan-Jeng |title=Taiwan's Democratization: A Summary |journal=World Affairs |date=Fall 1992 |volume=155 |issue=2 |pages=58–61}}</ref> Taiwan's pro-democracy movement gained momentum during the early 1980s and coalesced into the formation of the [[Democratic Progressive Party]] in 1986. Over the next decade, Taiwan attempted to restore the civil rights promised in its constitution, culminating with the Taiwan's first direct presidential election in 1996.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rigger |first1=Shelley |title=Democratic Transition and Consolidation in Taiwan |journal=Paper prepared for Taiwan's Future in the Asian Century: Toward a Strong, Prosperous, and Enduring Democracy Conference |date=November 10, 2011}}</ref> Taiwan continues to move towards a consolidated democracy.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Diamond |first1=Larry |title=How Democratic is Taiwan? Five Key Challenges for Democratic Development and Consolitation |url=https://web.stanford.edu/~ldiamond/papers/taiwan.pdf}}</ref>
===Ghana=== In 1991, [[Ghana]] was listed as an autocratic regime with a polity score of negative seven. By the late 1990s and early 2000s, Ghana was an open anocracy. In 2005, Ghana successfully transitioned from an open anocracy to a democracy as it has retained a polity score of eight since 2006.<ref name="Polity4" /> A major part of Ghana's success can be attributed to its management of the electoral process in order to decrease electoral conflict.<ref name="Lexington Books"/> Since Ghana began having elections in 1992, strengthening government institutions such as a strong, independent electoral commission has decreased electoral conflict.<ref name="Lexington Books"/> The existence of civil society organizations and a media aimed at ensuring democratic principles have also helped manage electoral conflicts in Ghana. For example, Ghana's 2008 elections ended peacefully as political institutions were able to respond to electoral challenges and advance democratic principles and processes.<ref name="Lexington Books"/> However, some electoral conflicts remain on a small scale in Ghana such as ethnic vote blocking, vote buying, intimidation and hate speeches.<ref name="Lexington Books"/> Yet, even with these minor conflicts, Ghana has been able to transform from an anocracy to a democracy by decreasing electoral conflicts.<ref name="Lexington Books"/>
== Terminology ==
Use of the word "anocracy" in English dates back to at least 1950, when [[R. F. C. Hull]]'s reprinted translation of [[Martin Buber]]'s 1946 work ''Pfade in Utopia'' [''Paths in Utopia''] distinguished "''an''ocracy" ([[neoclassical compound]]: ἀκρατία ''akratia'') from "anarchy" - "not absence of government but absence of domination".<ref>{{cite book | last = Buber | first = Martin | authorlink = Martin Buber | translator = R. F. C. Hull | title = Paths in utopia | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=MXGSnCcRaUwC | accessdate = 2013-04-25 | series = The Martin Buber Library | origyear = 1949 | year = 1950 | publisher = Syracuse University Press | isbn = 9780815604211 | page = 43 | quote = [...] Kropotkin is ultimately attacking not State-order as such but only the existing order in all its forms; [...] his "anarchy", like [[Proudhon]]'s, is in reality "anocracy" (''akratia''); not absence of government but absence of domination. }}</ref>

{{Infobox Military Conflict |conflict='''Battle of Znaim''' |partof=the [[War of the Fifth Coalition]] |date=10–11 July 1809 |place=[[Znojmo]], [[South Moravian Region]] |result=Armistice |combatant1={{flagicon|Austrian Empire}} [[Austrian Empire]] |combatant2={{flagicon|France}} [[First French Empire]] |commander1=[[Archduke Charles of Austria]] |commander2=[[Auguste de Marmont]] on the 10th, joined by [[Napoleon I]] and [[André Masséna]] on the 11th |strength1=40,000<ref name="Baker1112">Ralph Baker in ''The Encyclopedia of the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars'' by Gregory Fremont-Barnes (main editor) (Santa Barbara: ABC-CLIO, 2006) 1112.</ref>-47,000 |strength2=10,000 on the 10th, joined by Masséna's reinforcements on the 11th totalling 30,000 |casualties1=5,300 |casualties2=3,100 }} {{Campaignbox Fifth Coalition}} The '''Armistice of Znaim''' was a ceasefire agreed between [[Archduke Charles, Duke of Teschen|Archduke Charles]] and [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon I]] on 12 July 1809 following the '''Battle of Znaim''', effectively ending hostilities between [[Austrian Empire|Austria]] and [[First French Empire|France]] in the [[War of the Fifth Coalition]].
Following defeat at the [[Battle of Wagram]], Archduke Charles retreated north into [[Bohemia]] hoping to regroup his battered forces. The French army had also suffered in the battle and did not give immediate pursuit. But two days after the battle, Napoleon ordered his troops north intending to defeat the Austrians once and for all. The French eventually caught up the Austrians at Znaim (now [[Znojmo]], [[Czech Republic]]) on 10 July 1809. Realising they were in no position to give battle, the Austrians proposed a ceasefire as Archduke Charles went to begin peace negotiations with Napoleon. However, Marshal [[Auguste de Marmont]] refused to observe the ceasefire and committed his XI Corps of around 10,000 men into battle. With Marmont greatly outnumbered, [[André Masséna]] had no choice but to support him. By 11 July, Masséna's corps had joined Marmont's in battle but the Austrians had also reinforced their position around Znaim. After two days of futile fighting, with both sides suffering similar casualties and neither side gaining any advantage, Napoleon finally arrived with news of an armistice and ordered Marmont to end the battle.
Although the Battle of Znaim was the last action between Austria and France in the war, a formal peace was not agreed until the [[Treaty of Schönbrunn]] was signed on 14 October 1809, which finally ended the War of the Fifth Coalition.
==Prelude== The immediate cause of the two-day Battle of Znaim was the decision of the Austrian commander in chief, Archduke Charles, to stage a rearguard action near the town of Znaim, about 80 kilometers north of [[Vienna]], in order to give his army time to withdraw its baggage train in safety toward [[Moravia]]. Marmont’s two combined French and [[Bavaria]]n corps were the first of Napoleon’s troops to arrive on the field following the course of the river [[Thaya]]. Believing that he faced only a rear guard, Marmont ordered his Bavarian troops to take the village of [[Dobšice (Znojmo District)|Tesswitz]] south of Znaim, while the rest of his troops attacked the village of [[Suchohrdly|Zuckerhandl]].<ref>Ralph Baker in ''The Encyclopedia of the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars'' by Gregory Fremont-Barnes (main editor) (Santa Barbara: ABC-CLIO, 2006) 1111-1112.</ref>
==Battle== The Bavarians succeeded in storming Tesswitz but were then thrown out by Austrian reinforcements. Marmont renewed the Bavarian attack, and Tesswitz was retaken, only to be lost soon after. The village changed hands a number of times during the day, this contest constituting the heaviest fighting the Bavarians saw in the whole campaign. Marmont had hoped to swing his cavalry in behind the Austrian rear guard, but on reaching high ground above Tesswitz, they were faced with five enemy corps. The French cavalry was forced to withdraw in the face of a large body of Austrian cuirassiers.<ref name="Baker1112"/>
Marmont was now engaged by 40,000 Austrian troops and was heavily outnumbered. His men nevertheless managed to hold on to both Tesswitz and Zuckerhandl overnight. Archduke Charles withdrew his forces into a strong defensive position situated so as to hold the north bank of the Thaya and Znaim. Napoleon arrived at Tesswitz at 10:00 A.M., and despite the fact that he had brought with him reinforcements of cavalry and artillery, he believed that his force was too weak to launch a full-scale attack. His plan therefore was to employ Masséna’s corps to pin the Austrians throughout the day and to await the corps of marshals [[Louis-Nicolas Davout]] and [[Nicolas Oudinot]], which would be able to arrive early on the twelfth. Masséna launched his attack on the extreme right of the Austrian position during midmorning and quickly seized the main bridge across the Thaya south of Znaim. His troops took two small villages and then advanced directly on Znaim. Charles meanwhile reinforced the Austrian position with two grenadier brigades, which advanced during a thunderstorm and initially threw the French back.<ref name="Baker1112"/>
The situation was stabilized by a body of French cavalry at approximately 7:00 P.M., when French and Austrian staff officers rode along the opposing lines announcing a cease-fire, which led to the signature of an armistice on the twelfth. Znaim was to prove the last action of the 1809 campaign. The two sides signed a treaty of peace at the [[Schönbrunn Palace]] on 14 October.<ref name="Baker1112"/>

'''Camp Nama''' was a military base in [[Baghdad]], [[Iraq]], originally built by the government of [[Saddam Hussein]], from which its name derives, and now used by Iraqi military forces. Purportedly, the original Iraqi name has been repurposed by U.S. personnel involved with the facility as a [[backronym]] standing for "Nasty Ass Military Area". == History == After the [[2003 U.S. invasion of Iraq]], the camp was taken over by elite American [[special operations]] forces. The main purpose of the camp was to interrogate prisoners for information about [[Jordan]]ian [[terrorist]] [[Abu Musab al-Zarqawi]]. The ''[[New York Times]]'' reported on 19 March 2006, the three-year anniversary of the U.S. invasion, that the elite unit, known as [[Task Force 6-26]], used the facility to interrogate prisoners both before and after the [[Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse]] scandal.{{cite journal | first=Eric | last=Schmitt |author2=Carolyn Marshall | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/19/international/middleeast/19abuse.html | title=Task Force 6-26: In Secret Unit's 'Black Room,' a Grim Portrait of U.S. Abuse| journal=New York Times |date=19 March 2006}} Some of the interrogation took place in "The Black Room," which used to be a torture chamber when Saddam's government ran the facility. The camp was the target of repeated warnings and investigations from U.S. officials since August 2003. There were placards around the camp that read "[[No Blood No Foul]]," a reference to the notion, described by a Pentagon official, that "If you don't make them bleed, they can't prosecute for it." Allegations of abuse were first reported in the mainstream U.S. media in 2005.R. Jeffrey Smith and Josh White, "Soldier Who Reported Abuse Was Sent to Psychiatrist," ''Washington Post'' (5 March 2005) p. A15. After the more extensive ''New York Times'' report in 2006, which was "based on documents and interviews with more than a dozen people," the independent organization [[Human Rights Watch]] issued a report documenting detainee abuse in Iraq. The report confirmed the charges about Camp Nama uncovered by the ''New York Times'', noting that "from 2003 to the present, numerous U.S. personnel and Iraqi detainees have reported serious mistreatment of detainees by the special task force, including beatings, exposure to extreme cold, threats of death, humiliation, and various forms of heavy interrogation. Many of these allegations have been contained in documents released to the American Civil Liberties Union and other human rights groups pursuant to Freedom of Information Act litigation."Human Rights Watch, ''"[http://hrw.org/reports/2006/us0706/ No Blood, No Foul": Soldiers' Accounts of Detainee Abuse in Iraq]'' 18:3 (July 2006). The report included an extensive interview with one Sergeant, using the pseudonym "Jeff Perry", who worked as an interrogator with the task force running the detention center. Sergeant "Perry" indicated that written authorizations were required for most abusive techniques, indicating that the use of these tactics was approved up the [[command hierarchy|chain of command]]:
There was an authorization template on a computer, a sheet that you would print out, or actually just type it in. And it was a checklist. And it was all already typed out for you, environmental controls, hot and cold, you know, strobe lights, music, so forth. Working dogs, which, when I was there, wasn’t being used. But you would just check what you want to use off, and if you planned on using a harsh interrogation you’d just get it signed off. I never saw a sheet that wasn’t signed. It would be signed off by the commander, whoever that was, whether it was O3 [captain] or O6 [colonel], whoever was in charge at the time. ... When the O6 was there, yeah, he would sign off on that. ... He would sign off on that every time it was done. Some interrogators would go and use these techniques without typing up one of those things just because it was a hassle, or he didn’t want to do it and knew it was going to be approved anyway, and you’re not gonna get in that much trouble if you get caught doing one of these things without a signature. Techniques involving outright assault—hitting, slapping, and beating—were apparently not on the list, but were regularly used at Nama, indicating that the harsh methods that were approved often degenerated into even harsher treatment in practice.
Human Rights Watch's senior researcher on terrorism and counterterrorism commented, "These accounts rebut U.S. government claims that torture and abuse in Iraq was unauthorized and exceptional – on the contrary, it was condoned and commonly used.""[http://hrw.org/english/docs/2006/07/19/usint13767.htm U.S.: Soldiers Tell of Detainee Abuse in Iraq]." ''Human Rights Watch'' press release (23 July 2006). === Investigation and inter-agency conflict === The reports of abuses inside Camp Nama were said to have outraged even seasoned CIA, FBI and DIA investigators accustomed to dealing with non-cooperative and hostile detainees, and to have provoked a culture clash between agencies and groups involved with the facility. By early 2004, one of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's top aides, Under-Secretary for Defense Intelligence [[Stephen Cambone|Stephen A. Cambone]], ordered a subordinate, DIA head Vice Adm. [[Lowell E. Jacoby]] to "get to the bottom" of any misconduct. By June 25, 2004, Admiral Jacoby wrote a two-page memo to Cambone, in which he described a series of complaints, including a May 2004 incident in which a DIA interrogator said he witnessed task force soldiers punch a detainee hard enough to require medical help. The DIA officer took photos of the injuries, but a supervisor confiscated them, the memo said. The memo provoked an angry reaction from Mr. Cambone. "Get to the bottom of this immediately. This is not acceptable," Mr. Cambone said in a handwritten note on June 26, 2004, to his top deputy, Lt. Gen. [[William G. Boykin]]. "In particular, I want to know if this is part of a pattern of behavior by TF 6-26." According to the ''New York Times'' article, General Boykin had earlier said (on March 17) through a spokesman that he told Mr. Cambone he had found no pattern of misconduct with the task force. The article does not provide further detail on Boykin's response to the investigation after Cambone's and Jacoby's intervention in June, 2004. === Transfer to LSA Anaconda === According to the ''New York Times'' article, in the summer of 2004, Camp Nama closed and the unit moved to "a new headquarters in Balad, 45 miles north of Baghdad." This would probably refer to Balad AB, also known as [[Logistics Support Area Anaconda]] and later as [[Joint Base Balad]]. Since the transfer the unit's operations are said to have been shrouded in even tighter secrecy. According to [[Thomas E. Ricks (journalist)|Thomas E. Ricks]] of the ''[[Washington Post]]'', a new "detainee center" has indeed been established at Camp Balad, under the auspices of a new unit, the [[Joint Special Operations Task Force]]; entry is not permitted to normal Army Rangers personnel.[http://www.williambowles.info/spysrus/taskforce_121.html Sarah Meyer's notes on TF121] === Prisoner abuse === British soldiers testified that:{{cite web |url=http://m.guardian.co.uk/world/2013/apr/01/camp-nama-iraq-human-rights-abuses |title=Camp Nama: British personnel reveal horrors of secret US base in Baghdad |last1=Cobain |first1=Ian |date=April 1, 2013 |website=The Guardian |access-date=July 22, 2016 }} * Iraqi prisoners being held for prolonged periods in cells the size of large dog kennels. * Prisoners being subjected to electric shocks. * Prisoners being routinely hooded. * Inmates being taken into a sound-proofed shipping container for interrogation, and emerging in a state of physical distress. == Special areas == === The Black Room === Detainees at the camp that were considered "high-value" were interrogated in "The Black Room," a dark mostly bare room with large metal hooks hanging from the ceiling. The guards often used loud rock 'n' roll or rap music to torment prisoners during interrogations. === Motel 6 and Hotel California === The ''New York Times'' mentions other whimsically named sections of Camp Nama, including Motel 6, "a group of securely constructed wooden holding cells constructed by the United States Navy Seabees of Charlie Company NMCB-1 Air-Det. Conditions were cramped, forcing many prisoners to squat or crouch", in a block of 6-by-8 cubicles known as Hotel California. These holding cells were constructed to hold the leaders and Individuals responsible for terrorist acts and murders. == See also == * [[Task Force 121]] ==References== {{CIAPrisons}} {{coord|33|14|50|N|44|13|18|E|region:IQ-BG_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}} [[Category:Closed military facilities of the United States in Iraq]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Baghdad]] [[Category:Black sites]] [[Category:Human rights abuses]]

[[Image:Govan Fairfield election address.jpg|thumb|Election address of three [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] candidates, [[Mary Barbour]], [[Manny Shinwell]], and [[Tom Kerr]], for the [[Govan]] Fairfield ward in the Glasgow Municipal elections of 1920.]]
An '''election address''' is the material sent out by a [[candidate]] during a political campaign. Election Addresses are normally only sent out during the [[election]] period itself. Other political leaflets are usually known by different names.
In UK [[United Kingdom general elections|parliamentary elections]], all candidates are entitled to have one '''election address''' delivered free, by [[Royal Mail]] to every voter in their constituency.
==External links== *[http://www.bris.ac.uk/is/library/collections/specialcollections/archives/#election Election addresses] Collection of election addresses of almost all of the candidates at every British General Election since 1892. University of Bristol Library Special Collections
